myst/export/appendix-j.-characters.html.title: Appendix J. Characters
myst/export/appendix-j.-characters.html.description:
Inspiration(transparency: i haven't finished the witcher books, but i know (spoilers) Geralt was at one point a member of the wild hunt but i dont know the circumstances) Geoffrey is a witcher. My problem with the witcher and it's world and themes is that it doesn't represent the monsters we become. Throughout all of his philosophy about what truly makes a monster, Geralt has a holier-than-thou attitude because he's a witcher. In that setting, he is holier than thou because he is the only person, that, though ridiculed, cannot become a monster. Ikkown and Geoffrey is different. While Geoffrey thinks he is a holier-than-thou monster hunter to begin with, he then has to watch his partner become a monster he must hunt; and he is no different. He is just as suceptible as the player and his partner under the right circumstances.
Geoffrey is a human bounty and beast hunter, seeking a prey that is rather close to his heart.
Geoffrey once had a partner, who shall go unnamed in respect for the dead. While chasing the largest bounty they'd ever seen, their fortune ran into a deep cavern in obvious danger of collapse, but greed drove them onwards. The ensuing struggle within triggered a cave-in, leaving Geoffrey and his partner trapped inside. While a nearby village eventually dug them out, they had turned to the flesh of their target for bread, and while Geoffrey made it out, his partner was a sickly yellow by the time they were freed. Within days of eating the corpse, his partner began to turn to something of legend. Geoffrey did not believe in the Wendigo before hand, but with his dearest friend turned as the vile beast out of his own hubris, Geoffrey knew he had to end his partners suffering. Geoffrey is a professional. When it comes to survival and the hunt, he has full confidence in his abilities. Geoffrey is deeply insecure about his values and if he is any different from the beasts he hunts. He tries to cover his unsettled soul up with being a merry and lively man.
William is a Telsh refugee turned drafted soldier returning to his closest friends after his tour of duty. The people who took him in when he was a newly incarnate Telsh refugee mean the world to him.
William is a stern but kind man, easily trusting but not easily tricked. The destruction he saw in Telok and as a soldier after have made him grizzled and wise beyond his years. All he wishes for is too return home and rest. While William is not a fanatic devotee of the Numein, he sees them as gods with power over Ikkown. William always keeps his cool and handles any situation with reason and compassion. He cares deeply for those close to him. He does not speak often but when he does it is firm and wise.
Veritas is nihilist, not absurdist, and so is not seeking a greated God. Veritas is a control character. While the other characters have stories of how they came to nihilism, Veritas does not. She is just a completely average person who is already nihilist.
Veritas is a drow grave robber suffering from Nihirizmus. She is the first companion encountered by the Pilgrim. Veritas is suffering from Nihirizmus and internal conflict over the worth of her life. She sees no point in living, but hasn't yet the guts to commit suicide.
Veritas is one of the people who, because of Nihirizmus, can see the truth of the Numein, and their lack of real power. She is not often vocal about this, for slandering the Numein can bring intense persecution and is even criminal in some areas. Veritas is not a readily open person as her views are contrary to most of Ikkown, but she sees the Pilgrim as a yet unbiased blank slate, and one who she may be open with as they have not yet been overcome by the rampant zealotism of most of Ikkown. Veritas is friendly but not easily trusting. She will offer a hand to one in need, but will not turn her back after. Veritas is nihilist and apathetic to the grand state of the world. Veritas speaks in common slang and is at home on the street.

myst/export/chapter-1.-penreim.html.title: Chapter 1. Penreim
myst/export/chapter-1.-penreim.html.description:
Pilgrim Penreim (pen-rame) is a crypt near the quiet fishing outpost of Mebut, on the northern tip of Myst. The newly incarnate leaving the crypt is a rare but not surprising sight, and the village is a welcoming place for those new to this world, providing a place to stay while they gather their bearings. And it is so for the Pilgrim; for as is customary in Ikkown, the character will be referred by the common translation of their crypt's name: Pilgrim.
Chapter 1 covers the incarnation and beginning of life for the Pilgrim, and their stay in Mebut before venturing into the wider world to seek purpose in life. In it they will meet companions to bring, and discover a bastard curse at their very core.This tale begins with incarnation. Read the following:In the cold and damp dark of a tarnished casket, you arise. The wood is not nailed down, and slides easily, allowing you to stand straight. You are alive. You stand within a crypt, walls inlaid with many a casket same as your own. In the shadows there is complete silence. If you close your eyes you could believe you were not alive, but the stale, dead air against your skin says otherwise.
Penreim is split into three rooms; two crypts, and one entrance hall with a shrine to the Numein. In the deepest room of Penreim, the Pilgrim incarnates. Equipment. Next to their casket lays gifts and relics of their previous inhabitant, including various equipment pieces. This includes the starting equipment from the characters creation.
Veritas. As the Pilgrim enters the second room, they may see a figure on the other side of the room with a Perception check of 15, lowering as they get closer to the figure. Once the Pilgrim makes themself known, Veritas will spin with dagger in hand, threatening not to get any closer, thinking the Pilgrim is a guardsmen or another grave robber like herself. She will relax upon hearing the Pilgrim is neither thing. As is customary, she will offer the Pilgrim a helping hand in getting their footing in this new life if the Pilgrim doesn't turn her over for grave robbery. Upon this agreement, she will become the first companion to join the Pilgrim's journey.
Wendigo. As the party approaches the shrine room of the crypt, a Perception check of 14 will reveal a scuffling sound, like a large creature ripping into something. Inside the room is a Wendigo, ripping into a fresh corpse laid in the crypt. It is weakened, with only half it's normal Hit Points, and obvious crossbow wounds. In it's injured form it's Strength is reduced to 8, and it's bite attack only does 1c4-1 damage. Upon the party entering the room, it will immediately charge the Pilgrim and attempt to bite it. After a taste of the Pilgrim's flesh though, the Wendigo will turn and flee in disgust. Unbeknownst to the party at the time, the Pilgrim's nature as a vampyre makes an atrocious meal for a Wendigo.
Exit. After the Wendigo flees, the party will exit into the permanent night air of Myst and see the lights of Mebut down towards the shoreline. Upon exiting Penreim, the party levels up.

Mebut is a sleepy fishing outpost on the northern tip of Myst, it's only draw being that it is the closest place one can dock when sailing from Lethuis. It's residents are well accustomed to the newly incarnate, living so near to a crypt, although it is still not a common occurrence.
Veritas. Upon entering Mebut, Veritas will inform the Pilgrim that she has a room in the Sleeping Giant inn, and she is headed there to rest, and the Pilgrim may stay with her for a rest. Afterwards they must head to Capidum, the governing city of Myst to register the Pilgrim.
Raxaken Military. A ship of Raxaken soldiers returning from their drafted service has docked in Mebut just hours ago, and most of them are milling around Mebut, in the Sleeping Giant, or still by the ship.
Sleeping GiantIt's Sleeping Giant but you could also take it as a Skyrim reference.The Sleeping Giant inn is, like the rest of Mebut, not soon to wake up. The tavern is rather lively this travel though, as the returned soldiers make merry with the meager stock of drink the Giant has to offer.
Soldiers. The soldiers filling the Sleeping Giant are mildly imbibed and open to conversation. Upon discovering the Pilgrim is newly incarnate, they drunkenly sing a strange song about life and death that is culturally sung in celebration of the incarnate. The soldiers then begin to talk about Raxaken politics, home, and the terrors of existence, and the Pilgrim may listen in. Their questions about the new world will be gladly answered by the soldiers. Geoffrey. In a corner of Sleeping Giant away from the soldiers rabble is a man polishing a fine crossbow with a grim look on his face. Upon approach, he will snap out of it and greet the Pilgrim warmly. He recognizes the Pilgrim is not a soldier, and not one of the regular faces of the Giant, and asks what brings them to Mebut. Upon learning that the Pilgrim is headed to Capidum, he proposes they travel together, as he is headed in that direction as well. If the Pilgrim accepts, he will join the party's travels.
Gudus. At one of the tables, a game of low-stakes Gudus is taking place. Here the Pilgrim will be taught by one of the soldiers and may have their first game.
William. If the Pilgrim did not encounter William at the Docks, they will find him in the Sleeping Giant. See B. Docks for details.
When the Pilgrim is ready to lay their head, they may rest in Veritas' rented room. In the midst of their rest, the Pilgrim will awake. Read the following.You awake with a burning desire, a hunger. Not a need for meat or mead though, but a feeling as though the very essence of your existence is seeping through the cracks in your ribcage. Blood. All at once, instinct takes over. You need blood.
Unbeknownst to the Pilgrim, their vampyrism has awakened after it's long sleep in the crypt. They must feed. The Pilgrim may make a Lore check; a 10 will recognize their condition as vampyrism, while a 15 will bring to mind important knowledge of Nihirizmus and how the spread of their curse may happen.
Veritas. Veritas is the easiest target, in the same room as the Pilgrim. Veritas does believe Nihirizmus though, and feeding on her will turn her, but the Pilgrim does not necessarily know this, though they may have inferred it through a combination of Lore and Insight, to know of Nihirizmus and recognize it in Veritas respectively. Soldiers. All throughout the Sleeping Giant, soldiers are resting or drinking or gambling. An isolated one of them would make easy pickings. Mebut. Outside the Giant, while most of the town is asleep, some sailors or merchants are still at work, while various degenerates roam the streets.
Abstinence. A Pilgrim who passes a Wisdom check of DC 18 may exert their willpower and hold themselves from sating their thirst. They will suffer from the effects of abstinence though (==placeholder for a backlink to the vampyre doc on chastity).After slaking their palette, the Pilgrim returns to a not-quite-peaceful rest. Upon resting, the party levels up, and chapter 2 ends.
At the docks, a ship of discharged Raxaken soldiers has docked, and is currently unloading various belongings and other goods sent with it for transport. The captain of this regiment (Veteran) is overseeing the proceedings.
William. Standing near the ship is a rare sight. A Telsh soldier who seems rather lost is searching his pack. On approach he kindly and sternly greets the Pilgrim, asking if they know the way to Capidum. William is looking for a traveling partner to return to Capidum and see his family along the way. If the Pilgrim accepts, William will join the party and stay the night at the Sleeping Giant.ToDo: More dock stuffA short side quest here would be nice. The docks need to be here, but are rather empty.

myst/export/chapter-2.-okultos.html.title: Chapter 2. Okultos
myst/export/chapter-2.-okultos.html.description:
WH40K Warp InspirationOkultos being the source of 'magic' is (heavily) inspired by the Warp/Immaeterium from Warhammer 40K. There are a few common lore explanations for magic in fantasy settings: Manifestation of willpower (fine but bland) It just exists (I like "this isn't irl earth, things are different because they are" explanations) Some sort of divine source Manipulation of cosmic energy In Warhammer 40K, while it's not called magic, magic exists through psychic abilities (which is reffered to as sorcery often). In Warhammer, the Immaeterium is an parrallel dimension of pure psychic and emotional energy, and harnessing that energy is the key to being a psyker. Okultos will act similar. I like this much more than magic because it feels much more gritty and grounded. Psychic energy and such (while not real) has a basis in real life, with peoples belief in souls and the like. It feels like something that could evolve and isn't as fantastical as a magic just exists explanation.
Only one written record exists trying to explain Okultos. In ———, a wizened sorcerer, soon to reach his death, choose to finish his life's work by gaining true knowledge of Okultos. He bonded his and his apprentice's eyes, and focus a dominion granting him one wish. As expected, the sorcerer died, but his apprentice viewed the events through his eyes, and wrote the following after the experience: "It was a gaping maw, being infinite in all directions, but existing only for a fraction of a moment—a single point in time, immeasurable, but containing everything." The apprentice never practiced sorcery again. His fate is unknown. - A History of Sorcery, Voxriss
Okultos is a world parallel to mans understanding and the laws of Ikkown; it is formed of pure energy, wrought by the suffering of the living in Ikkown—Okultos is made of pure emotion and psyche. The existence of Okultos is a fact known among all of the inhabitants of Ikkown, and while known by all, it is understood by a very few, and no man has every grasped it's true nature.
Okultos does not follow any laws of Ikkown. Man interprets Ikkown as a space with 4 dimensions—3 spatial which they can move through, and time, which they cannot—but Okultos is not so. Okultos is 5 dimensional, and the beings within it can move through 4. While a physical humanoid simply cannot exist in Okultos, the 4th dimension, time, connects both worlds. But, since Okultos' creatures can move through this 4th dimension, humanoids perceive Okultos as a place where time is fluid, and does not flow consistently with Ikkown, or at a consistent rate at all.
While Okultos is not inherently something to be feared, it is not something to turn your back on either. Okultos is filled with entities that only exist through mans emotions, and as such man must keep on feeling for them to exist; and pain is easier to bring than pleasure. The energies of Okultos are not all to mans detriment though. Some have learned to harness their psychic power and connection to Okultos, utilizing it in a form known as sorcery.
Okultos thrives on the triumphs and failures of mankind, and it rests on a fine balance. Most of the entities of Okultos seek to bring suffering upon Ikkown, simply because it is easier than seeking joy. This poses a problem: If Okultos were to bring the ultimate suffering, the death of mankind, it would be Okultos' ultimate victory. But it would bring their downfall in the same moment, as the end of mankind means the end of the psychic energy Okultos needs to exist. Okultos is divided on whether it is a worthwhile price to pay.Sorcery Exerts an aptitude: sounds dumb Cast an aptitude: Too magic-coded Actualizes an aptitude: Big word Enforce an aptitude: gets across the reality bending nature, but a little weird
Sorcery is the greatest boon Okultos has brought to mankind. Harnessing the psychic ability of man is a challenge, as not all have enough power to practice sorcery. It takes training from a young age to master it, but it is a powerful tool.
Different moral views of sorcery crop up from those who do not practice it. Some are apathetic, a tool is a tool, no matter it's form. Others see utilizing sorcery as colluding with the entities of Okultos, and abetting the downfall of mankind. Most governments do not take such a stance, as even with the dangers it poses, sorcery is too great a gift too overlook. Most governments require sorcerers to be sanctioned and carry a warrant, allowing them to practice.Sorcery is a well studied phenomena, and scholars have grouped and categorized all forms of it by three different rankings of power—how difficult it is too perform and how much effect it has on the world. Cantrips are minor focus of psychic forces, that can be performed by anyone with some potential and a little training. Use of a cantrip generally does not make one a sorcerer. Aptitudes are the majority of sorcery. Aptitudes are scaled from one through five, and concern all manner of psychic phenomena and ability.
Dominions are the greatest feat a sorcerer can perform. A dominion wears thin the boundary between Ikkown and Okultos, the alter the very fabric of the world as man understands it. Successful usage of a dominion often kills the sorcerer. Even if they survive, they will never practice sorcery again. Along with their power, all sorcery is also grouped by its annal, or the domain it affects. Sorcerers often specialize in an annal, devoting their life to mastering it's secrets.
Purity manipulates ones own psyche and enforces it upon Ikkown. While pure magic is the most powerful, it is also constrained by the limits of possibility. Things that are impossible are impossible without letting Okultos in.
Reality lets Okultos in. This sorcery utilizes the unnatural existence of Okultos to do things that should be seemingly impossible by mans knowledge of Ikkown. Reality takes Okultos' energy and creates something from nothing.
Life focuses on the contact of one entities psyche with another. It can heal or hurt, bring back the dead and influence the living. Life though, has no effect on anything that does not have it's own psychic connection to Okultos.
While most sorcerers rely on innate talent, some with less energy, but the capability of knowledge utilize occuli—petrified brains of Okultos creatures. Harnessing the nature of a being of pure psychic energy made manifest, they imprint their aptitudes upon it's still living flesh, bending it to their will. Occuli require immense training to use, and a sorcerer who has mastered them is known as an Occulus.While the psychic energy of sorcery is closely tied to the sorcerer, it can be imbued into an item, losing much of it's power. These objects are known as psionics. While the energy is separated from it's sorcerer, it retains a thin link. Because of such, when a humanoid comes in direct contact with a psionic, they feel the emotions of it's creator, far in the back of their mind. This phenomena has been studied in an attempt to read minds or communicate, but nothing has come of it.Some aptitudes create illusions of varying quality and perceivability. Mastery of illusions is measured in 2 parts: minor or major, and ethereal or perfect. Minor illusions are of little stature, no larger than a 4 square feet. Most minor illusions are of inanimate objects such as secret walls or doors, but can also be of small living things. Minor illusions often do not require their exerters full concentration.
Major illusions are any illusion larger than a minor one, and require much more sorcerous ability to maintain. They can range from a humanoid to a whole building (GM discretion), as long as the sorcerer can concentrate on it.
Ethereal illusions exist visually and auditorily. Ethereal illusions are detected immediately when coming close enough to touch them, or with a DC passive Perception check. Perfect illusions are effectively summoning, but for that they only last as long as the sorcerer concentrates. For all intents and purposes, they are real. Ethereal illusions can only be detected if one has reason to believe there is an illusion at play, and even then, they are still just as real.Accidental Legitimate & Logical SexismBecause birth doesn't exist in Ikkown, I've accidently introduced a major inequality in the sexes cause men are objectively better now. Dunno if I'll address this.
Numein do not cause incarnationThey claim they do and people believe it, but The Forgotten One created Okultos and the process of incarnation after the Numein messed up
While Okultos is, to an extent, the seat of man's fears, it is also the source of man's life. Okultos plays an irreplicable role in the beautiful process known as incarnation. When the Numein created Ikkown, they made 77,777 bodies, and placed souls within them. But eventually those bodies withered and died, and their souls formed Okultos. But the emotions of the first lives ever lived created more souls. The Numein saw this and thought it was very pure, and so they started the cycle of incarnation.
When a body dies in Ikkown, it's soul moves on to Okultos. The body is then placed in a crypt, and over around twenty barters, the body will heal. Even from a death so destructive as burning to ash, the form can be regrown from a shard of a fingernail, though it may take upwards of hundreds of barters. Once the body is prepared to live again, a newly made soul will be cast into it from Okultos, and the body will live again.
Incarnation is an invasive process. The new soul does not share any memory of the form's previous host, but some skill is retained. Knowledge mastered to the point of muscle memory may be carried over to a new life, manifesting in the form of a natural giftedness towards those subjects. Common knowledge is also retained, similar to effects like amnesia. A newly incarnated person knows of the Numein and of Myst and Teirium, but they do not understand, as they have no experience.
Names in Ikkown are chosen by the person when they feel they have completed a task in life that defines them as a person. Till then, the new incarnate often adopts the name of the crypt they incarnated in. Names are powerful, and choosing one should not be taken lightly. Once an action that truly identifies a person is completed and they choose their name, it is quite literally set in stone on the walls of the Annals of Voxriss.
Life—if it can be called that—abounds in Okultos just as it does in Ikkown. Although it takes a different form, similar principles exist in the society of Okultos. While a culture as complex as Ikkown exists, only three entities have the power to make contact with Ikkown and be known.
The Emperor, whose Teelul name is Keizor'no, is known to be the greatest power in Okultos. He rules with an iron fist, ensuring Ikkown produces enough energy for Okultos to thrive, but preventing the Destruction Paradox. He often pacts with warlocks of Ikkown, and at times has even been active in the politics of Ikkown through his warlocks.
The Demoness is the, to use Ikkown's way or perceiving, 'young' rebel looking to overthrow the Emperor. She is rabid for bloodshed in Ikkown, throwing caution to the wind. She does not believe in the Destruction Paradox, preaching that the ultimate victory would end Okultos' reliance on man to survive.
The Forgotten One refers to an entity that at one point existed and interacted with Ikkown, but has not been recorded on Ikkown since before the Meifesta Sorei. Recorded is a strong word here. Myths and rumors speak of his existence, but it is generally regarded as heresy among followers of the Numein, and the credibility of those who speak of these accounts is hogwash at best because they weren't alive thousands of barters ago.
Talking about The Forgotten OneThe Forgotten One's existence is rumored, but by the 3rd barter of the Age of the Downfall of Telok, he is nearly entirely lost to history. Man has not even considered that something of his nature could exist, as it is a well guarded secret by the Numein.
All references to The Forgotten One before chapter 5 of the campaign should be vague at best. The player must believe they are alone in the world.GodThe Forgotten One is a God allegory, with the time he dissapears for representing the 500 years of silence before Jesus comes.

myst/export/chapter-3.-the-numein.html.title: Chapter 3. The Numein
myst/export/chapter-3.-the-numein.html.description:
RedoThis file is rather (very very) on the nose about the Numein. They are widely (99%) worshipped, the whole greater truth thing is completely unknown to literally everybody in Ikkown except vampyre lady at the start of the game.Numein RepresentationThe Numein are gods but not God. The Numein represent the 3 major categories of wordly things people worship instead of the real God. The Numein only have the power people give them, they have effect on Ikkown, but extend no more.
The Numein are the major super-humanoid forces at work in Ikkown, and they are worshiped as gods; they are not.
Many humanoids worship and revere the Numein, as their power over humanoids and Ikkown seems god-like, and to an extent, it is. They have great control over the lives of man and the happenings in Ikkown, but their power is very strongly limited. The average mind of man fails to see the bigger picture; the Numein may control worldly events, but that is all. At most, the Numein bring fleeting happiness, but they have not defeated death. Followers of the Numein ultimately prostrate themselves before beings whose power is just as limited as their own, but have deceived the fool into believing it can make something of nothing.
The Numein are sevenfold, separated into three groups, Madiven, the Triad, & the Triptych. Madiven is the foremost of them all, but is also the most neutral. While Madiven is worshiped, his worshipers do not believe in much besides him, and he is a largely neutral if not apathetic entity. The Triad is made of Vritsu, Dikum, and Mortud, and represents a largely altruistic view of existence. The Triptych exists on the opposite side, where Libeva, Geluna, and Shizuur offer a self-gratifying worldview.Numein Sybollogy Madiven His symbol represents apathy, but power above A throne, looking down on the world The Triad Vritsu: She represents kindness and selflessness Clasped hands Dikum: Generosity A coin falling into an open hand Mortud: Professional dedication to greater good A shining city The Triptych Libeva A fist clamps a bag of money as a head rolls Geluna Dice fall on mountain peaks Shizuur The wine glass, overflowing Numein Individual Representation Madiven: Neutrality, apathy, just not caring about the greater meaning of existence The Triad: Escaping death by doing good in life Vritsu: Kindness Dikum: Generosity Mortud: Care (professional) The Triptych: Pleasing oneself as much as possible before death innevitably comes Libeva: Greed Geluna: Adventure, discovery, luck Shizuur: Sloth
Once, a regionally popular bard in Douris sang a ballad, claiming to be the story of how the Numein and Ikkown came to be. It was played once, met with cries of "dunt lunus" and "meugloval". And the bard was mocked out of his career. While the ballad's story was met with jeers by the commoners and priests of the Numein, the few who understood the true state of existence knew of it's truth. The following is a summary of it's contents, as the original verse has been lost to time. The ballad was entitled Madiven, the Triad, & the Triptych, or the Vices of Man. \O one we have forgot! Remind us of a tale, Preerus! Who suffered not the lies of our fallen gods.And so he stood, before Madiven, one they call Creator! Lord! And god! One of three, no falsehood."Give up this task in vain, your woeful existence means not but to be slain, betrayed by one you call Schietor"Two cycles of the heavens before, Ikkown was naught but a thought.
Only had there been, Madiven,[1] The Triad, The Triptych.Half-gods of empty worlds, created by one truth, by power eternal the one called Schietor.But these seven Numein, they could not bow down. Schietor offered them freedom, but one command:"Do not create life, or you shall be cast down among it."But the Numein in pride, brought upon themselves their fall. When Preerus, the first man, was made, Schietor called."Preerus. Come and see the downfall of your creators."His voice booms like thunder, and Preerus can do naught, but fall prostrate in awe and wonder before glory.On his journey to the place Schietor called him, Preerus met temptation. Both good and evil.Here the meter goes to 7/4I had to change Diakumu's name to Dikum to fit the meter hereThe Triptych. Valsai Kwaarum. Libeva offers the self. Geluna, the unknown. Shizuur, ease, comfort, and sloth."The path of least resistance will make no man."The Triad. Valsai Yonum. Vritsu offers selflessness. Dikum, generosity. Mortud values selfless love."All these are good, but none will make your life meaningful."Here the meter goes back to 6/4And the first, Madiven. Valsai Mathia. The greatest sin of all: Nihirizmus. Apathy."What truly is the worth of your short mortal life? You will die and have no effect beyond that death.But Preerus feels the call. There is something beyond, something truly eternal. Who gives purpose to all.The Numein were made man. With power over Ikkown, but neither death nor life. Undying, not immortal.And in that finite point, Schietor's glory shown. True creator and lord."Be still, and know that I am God.”But when Preerus returned, exalting his Lord's glory, he found his fellow men had been deceived.In shock and awe, they lay, prostrate fore the Numein. Near-sighted to their death, eternity forgotten.And so Preerus resigned himself to the mountains, to watch mankind decay. To be lost in foolishness.Schietor forgotten, he slumbers awaiting the day of emergence, when salvation comes to man.
This breaks the meter, Madiven is 3 syllables↩︎

myst/export/chapter-4.-vampyrs.html.title: Chapter 4. Vampyrs
myst/export/chapter-4.-vampyrs.html.description:
Nihilism, Vampires, and the Heart of MeThis is the true heart of Myst. This is the center of my theological arguments and the entire theme and point of my life. I love vampires. They've always been my favorite fantasy design because they are unlike anything else. They are 100% man and 100% monster, the same as real humans. They are a wonderful paradigm of sinful nature, and they bring the true monster within every fallen man to light. There is no redeeming them. There is no cure. You are a blasphemous scourge to be raised upon a stake and burned, with no salvation. Some vampire stories take advantage of this. But they often do not take the next step in the analogy. Stopping there leaves only nihilism. That is what a vampire is for someone with no salvation. An embodiment of the pointless life they live. Nihilism. If I was not a Christian I would be dead, but in a parallel universe where I don't kill myself, I would be a raging nihilist; and with the information that I would have, I would be right to an extent. entropy noun, en-tro-py 2.a: the degradation of the matter and energy in the universe to an ultimate state of inert uniformity "Entropy is the general trend of the universe toward death and disorder." - James R. Newman 3: Chaos, Disorganization, Randomness Meriam Webster The world we live in is an illogical one. It does not make sense. It is inconsistent, chaotic, disorganized, and random. Embracing this will only lead to madness, as we see in the world right now. Leaning on logic tells us nihilism: that the story ends here, that there is no explanation for existence. It is Chaos. Warhammer 40,000 is one of my biggest inspirations in this regard. In the grim darkness of the far future, there is only war. 40K coined the term grimdark, and created a genre. An average person would tell you that grimdark settings are hopeless, existence is futile, and at best nothing at all awaits beyond the veil. All of this is true, but people often fail to make the connection. Our world without a God is a grim dark place. Grimdark settings are nihilism embodied. In 40K, Chaos is not only personified, but factionized. Chaos is a person, and that person represents the madness wrought by accepting an illogical existence. But once again, the analogy ends there. There is no God in 40K. Ikkown is a grimdark setting. Most people live to serve lesser deities who cannot prevent death, even if above it themselves. Their life is pointless. I wrote nihilism to be a disease, an affliction: Nihirizmus. I did so because the player simply understands the analogy better when nihilism isn't some mental concept, it is a real thing that affects you once you believe it. Once a person has contracted Nihirizmus, they are susceptible to becoming a vampyre, and becoming nihilism and sinful nature embodied. And that is it to start with in Ikkown. God is still in his 500 years of silence, and so life is hopeless. I want to pause and take a deeper look at the different types of nihilism. I have chose to break it into 3 for my representations here. Existential + Moral: This is conventional nihilism. Life is meaningless, morals are baseless, but they don't have the guts to kill themselves yet. Epistemological: These believe that thinking too deep about existence will drive you just as mad as accepting it. Both roads lead to damnation, and so let anarchy reign. Absurdism: This is the belief that as the world is illogical, there must be a secret, a key to the door. This rests on the pillar belief that the world must be logical. The problem with all 3 of these as worldviews is that they are temporary. They are a worldview that has not reached its endpoint yet. For someone who is truly existentially and morally nihilistic, the end conclusion is suicide. Epistemological nihilism is just chaos; there is no thought. Absurdism is an active search for a meaning to existence, not an endpoint. So what does a vampyre really represent in Myst. They are sinful nature that is unaware it is reedemable.
Beasts of all kinds are common in Ikkown, but the vampyre stands unique among them. The vampyre is both man and beast, and the only one of it's kind. They are monsters feared by the all untainted men, walking only during the night. To all men, vampyres are viewed as a stain, an imperfection on an otherwise clean world. There is no grace to be found for their kind. They are truly the scum of the earth, to be excised like a tumor. They are worthless.
The common man understands vampyrism as a disease—and it is true that it is spread like one—but in truth, it is an infection not of the body but of the mind. Vampyres suffer from Nihirizmus: the knowledge their life is a worthless blight upon Ikkown, and all the good they could do can never outweigh their inherently evil nature. Nihirizmus is the primordial truth of the universe for all men—that they are imperfect and finite, and the world will begin and end the same with or without them. Nihirizmus is just made abundantly clear to a vampyre.
To contract vampyrism, the man must first suffer Nihirizmus, then be bit by a vampyre. Incarnation heals a body of almost any ailment, disease, or injury imaginable, but for vampyrism. Ultimately, vampyres rest in the grasp of a destruction paradox, similar to Okultos. Every body in the world will eventually be infected, and every body in the world will die from a lack of blood, as no pure man still treads Ikkown.
Over the course of a few travels, the infected will feel Nihirizmus take a much stronger grasp on their mind. Then, they will develop fangs, and an aversion to the sun. Over another travel, these effects strengthen to create what is known as a full vampyre. The vampyre will develop various abilities, which are seemingly random. They may have minor shapeshifting, such as changing their face. Near-invisibility in shadow. The possibilities are not well recorded. After first using these abilities, the Thirst will set. A vampyre consumes a minuscule amount of their own blood simply to live, but usage of their vampyric powers brings on a much larger consumption. And so they must feed.
Vampyres may not enter the homes of men without invitation. In reality, this has nothing to do with being a vampyre. One of the protections offered by the Numein to their followers is a shelter around their home. No beast is able to enter the place where a follower lays their head, and vampyres are monsters. Being both man and monster, the man may be invited, but the monster is otherwise blocked.
GM's Note: Granting EntryAs the GM controlling what all NPCs say and do, it is ultimately up to you to decide when vampyre characters should be able to enter a location. Ultimately, vampyres gain entry in one of three ways:
Unsolicited Invitation. Characters with no reason to suspect a character of anything have no reason not to allow them into their home. If a character is in anothers good graces, no trickery is required. Some homes are also open to the public. For instance, if a tavern's owner sleeps in an apartment on top of it, as long as the tavern is open the whole building is fair game for a vampyre. Similarly, if the owner of a home leaves doors or windows unlocked, knowlingly or unknowlingly, the Numein consider this a sign the building is public, and therefore vampyres may enter without explicit invitation.
Charisma. Characters who are not trusting the party but do not know they are a vampyre can be convinced with Charisma and a good reason to invite a vampyre in.
Trickery. For a known vampyre, gaining entry requires trickery. This may come in the form of a Deception check to illicit a slip of the tongue, or convincing a party-goer who is allowed to bring a friend to invite the vampyre.
Douris, as well as being the center of the world, is the center of vampyrism. As the sun does not rise on Myst, and even continental Douris has rather long nights, many vampyres migrate in search of a safer home.
Without motivation, vampyres are often isolationist creatures, living quiet lives as craftsmen or artists, going out at night to feed. In Douris though, a group known as the Coven formed; a congregation of vampyres, with no particular goal, but simply for company, or allies when times get tough.
In recent history though, the Coven united for an attempt on the isle of Myst. They viewed it as a chance to create a safe haven for their kind, in a place where night still reined. It was led by the most powerful vampyre to live in recorded history, simply called the Lord. The coup almost succeeded, but was squashed by Raxake's military might.
After the attempt on the isle of Myst, the Coven splintered into 4 subfactions, each vying for a different view of how the isle should be ruled. The lines dividing the factions were ultimately drawn by different reactions to Nihirizmus, and still divide the Coven to the current travel.ToDo: Expand on the lore of coven subfactions
Mathia is the largest group within the Coven, and the most common belief about Nihirizmus. Mathia holds thus: "Existence exists. Not for a purpose, but simply because it does. Life will go on with or without us, and what we do does not matter, for all will turn to our way in the end." Unknown Those who will follow Mathia often take part in suicide cults.illogicAnsaich believes that the other views of Nihirizmus look too deep into it. They believe in anarchy. Life is pointless, so kiri, do whatever you want.Bakursus believes existence is illogical and absurd. It is unnatural, and the purpose of life is to discover what made this world and why it is this way.
Bakursus sees the world through this lens. The Numein did not make the world, and so something greater must have, for nature did not. The world is illogical, and does not make sense, and nature is cold and logical; logic cannot create illogic. There must be a feeling power that brought this world into being.
Vobidashi feels a calling, that there is something greater in existence than living and dying. While man feels this call and prostrates themselves before the Numein, Vobidashi sees the Numein for the cast down husks of a god they are, and seeks something more.

myst/export/glossary.html.title: Glossary
myst/export/glossary.html.description:
A Primer to Reading a Sourcebookplease please feel free to ask me questions because you are diving into the ~ point of a currently 2 year project; it will be a mess. this glossary will try to define important terms without making you read a full chapter about that thing, but if you are at all interested in reading the full chapter for that topic shoot me a text, i'll gladly take all the eyes i can get A TTRPG sourcebook is not read like a normal story. It is in the 2nd omniscent person. It is written to the GM (Game master/manager), who is the one running the game for the players, who create characters to play through the story (campaign). It's function over form. While I try to keep the writing itself interesting, getting the content across clearly is more important than the GM having fun reading the book. While you will see just one chapter of the book, there is a whole lot more than just X chapters. This glossary will try to summarize important terms but a good ~100 pages of setting and gameplay comes before this. It is non-linear. A 'chapter' more or less consists of a location and everything that could happen there depending on what the players do. Some things may never come up and some will turn out completely different depending on who plays. While the majority is story, there is chunks relating to gameplay (which will be fairly obvious). I will try to mark gameplay stuff that is unimportant from a strictly narrative perspective. Notes about my writing specifically: I use light language. I have a doc about this somewhere, if I don't attach it to however this gets posted ask me about it if you want. Not everything I've written is included in this rn, only whats relevant to chapter 1. Chapter 1 also links to various other pieces that are relevant if you want to read those. Chapter 1. Penreim
Incarnation: Ikkown is a sexless world. When people die, the natural process of incarnation takes over. The soul will leave it and move on, but the body will regrow over time, ranging from just weeks to years depending on how damaged the body was. After that period, a new soul will be placed within and the body will live again. There are 77,777 bodies, there always have been, and always will be.
Ikkown: Teelul for world. Ikkown is the physical world and setting as a whole. Ikkown is a medium fantasy setting. High fantasy is a setting where basically all modern tech exists, but is explained away with magic etc, while low fantasy is medieval times except that weird woman in the forest is actually a witch and the Chupacabra did actually rape your peasant daughter. In medium fantasy, not everybody and their dog is throwing fireballs but the 'fantastic' elements of the setting do play a major role.
Numein: The Numein are cast-down demigods of Ikkown who have fooled mankind into believing they are true gods. There are 7, comprising Madiven, the Triad, and the Triptych. Each of the Numein represent one of the vices of mankind. Teelul: The language spoken before Teirian common.
The Forgotten One/Schietor: This is God (not literally but a hard analogy). He created the The Numein, the Numein created the world. He cast them down. Mankind fell for a belief in the lesser deities of the Numein while The Forgotten One fell silent for a time.
Vampyres: vampyres in Myst are stripped down compared to a typical fantasy vampire. Becoming a vampyre is 2 steps: 1. Contract Nihirizmus, which a disease manifestation of internal nihlism 2. Get bit by a vampyre. Once a body is infected, even incarnation won't heal it. vampyres are normal people except they need to drink blood to live and burn in sunlight ('stripped down' as in no sleeping in coffins, silver bullets or stakes, no superstrength, no turning into a bat. there are no upsides to vampyrism). vampyrism is an analogy for the sinful nature of man.
Douris: The major continent that most of this campaign is set on.
Raxake: is the kingdom in control of Douris and Myst.
Myst: An island west of Douris, it is a vassal state of Raxake. Myst is notable as the sun has not risen on Myst in ages.

myst/export/part-3.-ikkown.html.title: Part 3. Ikkown
myst/export/part-3.-ikkown.html.description:
In-World IntroI was already considering writing an in-world short story following a body & soul dying, but this was also an assignment for CW which sealed the deal (even though this isn't what I turned in) Important parts of Ikkown as a setting that must be introduced: Incarnation
Okultos Sorcery Vampyres
Numein
Teirium & Douris Myst Use a decent bit of Teelul Breakdown Body is near destroyed, soul exits
Soul goes to Okultos
Transfer camera to the new soul leaving Okultos after having a glimpse of what dwells within
Helps emphasize that the spiritual (Okultos) is just as much if not more important than the physical (Ikkown)
The soul exits Okultos, where the camera begins to perceive linear time once more, a hundred years have passed and the body has been crypted and regenerated
As the soul enters Ikkown for a new body, a birds eye view of Ikkown is seen
Temples of the Numein
Covens of vampyres
Armies in Teirium
The rich study of sorcery in Douris But a strange darkness covers Myst, and it can't be penetrated The soul incarnates in Telok, just before it's destruction This is set 3 barters before the player is incarnated, the day of the Age of the Downfall of Telok. Numein use the word "true" to much for something explicitly false Zimashi x2 "mankind wallows"? heck does that mean As the body burns, a zimashi exits—a life force, soul as some call it. But souls are not of the physical realm, and the tie between the physical and the spiritual is snipped.
The spiritual is not something easily considered by the mind of man. Okultos is what their limited tongues call it, but a name cannot be applied to existence itself. As the soul dives deep into an abyss of spacelessness, time passes, stands till, and reverses. For the spirit is eternal. No, perpetual. Eternity spans in both directions, but existence is still an immutable point. Okultos is not trifled by this concept of the present. It is perpetual.
Within the spiritual lie many entities. Zimashi. Souls yet to be made manifest and souls whose body is past them exist simultaneously. Yet more souls exist. Souls which will never be made physical. They hold the true power, as they want not for the flesh. Above them all, an Emperor sits upon his throne. Amidst them all, an evil stirs chaos. Below them all, something greater waits. Dormant, but not imperceptive. It has laid silent for millions of souls, but it's rest is short to come.
But in Ikkown, much time has passed, and body has healed. Incarnation begins. As a new soul is called from Okultos, and begins to breathe life into the once-burnt body, the rest of mankind wallows, just as it has for all time before.
The Numein sit on their thrones. Valsai Kwaarum. The Triptych. Beauty and indulgence incarnate. A true worshipping of the self. Valsai Yonum. The Triad. Good and love manifest. Putting the greater good of others before ones self. A wonderful pastime. Valsai Mathia. In this rests the true power. Madiven sits above all, unquestionably the greatest of the Numein; yet he is neutral. He has no greater purpose. He is a fraud, just as they all are. Powerless over death or time. False evil, false good, false apathy.
In Teirium, one man gathers a multitude. Driven by hunger, they hover as an impending doom over free civilization. In Douris, they are ignorant. They refuse to believe that there could be war. The very people whose ancestors so long ago left their neighbors land under their conviction of meifesta sorei are now threatened by one with an even stronger belief: they must fill their stomachs. The wanton study of sorcery and the spiritual practiced in Douris will not fill stomachs, nor will it push back a hundred swords. But for now, the Teirians are plump, and have time to prepare.
And in a moment, life is brought a sliver closer to it's inevitable end; one vampyre becomes two. The wonder of incarnation can heal most any wound, and rebuild a body from the ash of a stake-burned traitor. But it cannot cure vampyrism. It is simply that body's nature, no matter the soul. And so Nihirizmus takes another. When there is no blood left to feed? Maybe new life will take hold. Maybe a body will be incarnated, simply to thirst for something which does not exist and die. A cruel world it is.
But towards the isle of Myst, a strange darkness lurks. Impenetrable by the spiritual and physical eye. For once the sun never rose on Douris or it's sister isle. But light shines on the land now. The sun never rose over Myst though, and so darkness gathers there. An assured evil lives there. Deep in the crypts of Myst, a possibly greater evil lies dormant. It's awakening will spell catastrophe.
But this soul is not going to any of the those places. Instead, it's body slumbers in the deep. In the ancient city of Telok, below the surface of the waves. The Telsh have sparked the first war with Teirium, and Telok is not long for this world. Teirium's sorcery will shake the earth and bring the ground in upon itself, and the Telsh will flee to land. But the Telsh are an inconsequential race in the world of Ikkown. And so it is. Physical and spiritual. Ut bona ut instaata.
ToDoNot sure if I want to end the Ikkown intro right here or include a more standard overview as well. All things important are detailed normally in chapters 3.1-3.4 and so I could leave this as a fun intro page.

myst/export/part-7.-myst.html.title: Part 7. Myst
myst/export/part-7.-myst.html.description:
Part 7 is the campaign that Ikkown and this book is designed for. If you are a player, stop reading here! From this point on, this book assumes you are the GM. \
The Myst campaign is split into ten chapters, one for each player character level.
As the GM, you must understand some things about Ikkown to run this campaign. While the contents of Parts 3 and 5 are true for the most part, all is not as it seems. The following is information known by little too nobody in the world of Ikkown, but plays a major role in the story, and will become apparent to your player as it progresses.
The Numein are false deities. The Numein did not create Ikkown, though they did create mankind. They have power over the physical realm of Ikkown, but no power over life or death.
The Forgotten One is very real and is returning. Also known as Schietor, while Ikkown has forgotten him, he has slumbered preparing his return. Schietor is the original creator of the Numein and Ikkown, and did not create mankind in their imperfect form, but is soon to come and redeem them.
The player character has incarnated into the body of the original Lord of the Coven, and will slowly gain much of the power that comes with such a form.

myst/export/swearing.html.title: Swearing
myst/export/swearing.html.description:
Here is a do/don't/replace on swearing.
❌ Hell Not lore friendly, hell doesn't exist ✅ Damn
✅ Bastard "something that is spurious"
"an offensive or disagreeable person"
"of abnormal shape or irregular size"
(sex doesn't exist it's not male bitch) ❌ Bitch Old English meaning is female dog and I don't know why I would ever need to reference female dogs ⭕ Shit Teelul: gloval, meugloval (bullshit) ⭕ Fuck Teelul: kiri, kiri dont (fuck you) ⭕ (insert non-sexual crude reference to the body) Teelul: Lunus (catch all term) Me swearing The Bible says to let nothing foul exit your mouth. I interpret this by meaning, not by word. Saying fuck as an exclamation is fine but fuck you is saying something foul and targeted at a person. I think cursing is crude in general though, and overuse of curse words makes them lose their meaning. I swear rarely for emphasis, but I don't think there's anything inherently sinful about the word fuck. Characters swearing In complete isolation, I have no problem with writing characters that swear out the ass (haha) and do sinful things that sinful people do. However, not everybody shares that opinion and ultimately what I make has to get approval from people who don't agree.
